item.title: Mahmoud Abbas to Resign P.L.O. Leadership Position, Officials Say
item.description: Mr. Abbas would quit as head of the executive committee in a maneuver apparently designed to boost his legitimacy within the organization, committee members said.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: One Year After War, People of Gaza Still Sit Among the Ruins
item.description: Not a single one of the nearly 18,000 homes destroyed or severely damaged in last summerâ€™s war is habitable, despite an Israeli mechanism to approve reconstruction.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN and MAJD AL WAHEIDI
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Few of the thousands of homes destroyed in last summer's war between Israel and Palestinian militants in Gaza, including in Beit Lahiya, have been rebuilt.

item.title: 3 Who Stopped Train Attack Were Boyhood Friends
item.description: The three Americans who subdued a gunman aboard a train to Paris are friends from their middle-school days, and two of them serve in the armed forces.
item.dc:creator: ASHLEY SOUTHALL
item.media:credit: Left, Philippe Huguen/Agence France-Presse; center and right, Pascal Rossignol/Reuters
item.media:description: From left, Airman First Class Spencer Stone, Alek Skarlatos, a specialist in the Oregon Army National Guard, and Anthony Sadler, a friend of the two servicemen.

item.title: Pakistan Cancels Talks With India, Citing Restrictions
item.description: High-level talks had been scheduled for Sunday and Monday, but both sides traded barbs over Pakistanâ€™s plans to meet with Kashmiri separatist leaders.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Shabab Bombing Kills at Least 11 at Somali Army Camp
item.description: The Islamist militant group, which has ties to Al Qaeda, claimed responsibility in a suicide bombing that killed at least 11 people at a training camp in Kismayo.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: One Killed in Explosion at China Chemical Site
item.description: The explosion on Saturday, which tore through a chemical plant in Zibo, Shandong Province, also injured at least nine people.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Ieng Thirith, Khmer Rouge Minister in Cambodia, Dies at 83
item.description: Ms. Ieng Thirith, the most powerful woman in a brutal regime and Pol Potâ€™s sister-in-law, was found unfit for trial in 2012 because of dementia.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Speaker of Pakistan Assembly Is Removed in Election Dispute
item.description: Sardar Ayaz Sadiq was unseated after an election tribunal declared that his victory in 2013 was marred by irregularities.
item.dc:creator: WAQAR GILLANI

item.title: Train Attack in Europe Puts Focus on Vulnerability of U.S. Rail
item.description: Unlike airports, with their multiple security layers, most railroad stations have minimal protections for those boarding trains.
item.dc:creator: RON NIXON
item.media:description: Police officers patrolled the platforms of the Brussels-South train station on Saturday.

item.title: Migrants Rush Across Border in Macedonia
item.description: Thousands of refugees managed to get past a cordon set up to prevent them from crossing into the country from Greece.
item.dc:creator: ALEKSANDAR DIMISHKOVSKI

item.title: A Shot, a Glimpse of an AK-47, and U.S. Servicemen Pounced on Gunman on Train to France
item.description: The quick action by two servicemen on a high-speed train traveling from Amsterdam to Paris averted what officials said could have been a blood bath.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Left, Philippe Huguen/Agence France-Presse; center and right, Pascal Rossignol/Reuters
item.media:description: From left, Airman First Class Spencer Stone, Alek Skarlatos, a specialist in the Oregon Army National Guard, and Anthony Sadler, a friend of the two servicemen.

item.title: 7 Dead as Fighter Jet Crashes Into Highway at British Airshow
item.description: A fighter jet taking part in a British airshow in West Sussex, on Englandâ€™s southern coast, crashed into a busy road.
item.dc:creator: DANNY HAKIM

item.title: A British House Overflowing With Lords Draws Scorn
item.description: Amid European disenchantment with political institutions, criticism of the ever-expanding legislative chamber, the largest outside China, is mounting.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: The House of Lords in London. Both the chamberâ€™s size, at 781 members, and its behavior have brought it scorn.

item.title: Kabul Suicide Bombing Kills 12, Including 3 Americans
item.description: A suicide car bomber targeted the vehicle of the Americans, employees of the military contractor DynCorp International, according to Afghan and American accounts.
item.dc:creator: AHMAD SHAKIB and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: The site of an explosion in the center of Kabul on Saturday, where 12 people were killed by a suicide car bomber.

item.title: Profile Emerges of Suspect in Attack on Train to Paris
item.description: The gunman is believed to be Ayoub El Kahzani, of Moroccan origin, who was known to the Spanish and French security services and is reported to have traveled to Syria last year.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Christina Catherine Coons/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: The police detained a suspect at a train station in the French city of Arras on Friday.

item.title: Strategies: Currency Devaluation Is a Short Step in Chinaâ€™s Long Advance
item.description: A modest devaluation of the renminbi, part of Chinaâ€™s decades-long transformation into a modern economy, may help the country stave off domestic pressures.
item.dc:creator: JEFF SOMMER

item.title: Investors Race to Escape Risk in Once-Booming Emerging-Market Bonds
item.description: A selling spree by large mutual funds has raised concerns among regulators and economists about a broader contagion if investors start to ask for their money at the same time.
item.dc:creator: LANDON THOMAS Jr.
item.media:description: The Chinese yuan. Chinaâ€™s decision to devalue its currency set off a chain reaction of panicked selling around the world.

item.title: After 70 Years of Men, Some Say It Is â€˜High Timeâ€™ a Woman Led the U.N.
item.description: Growing calls for a woman to lead the United Nations reflect not only an appeal for gender equity but also frustration with the opaque way in which world powers bargain over the appointment.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Irina Bokova of Bulgaria, the director general of Unesco, has been brought up as a potential nominee for secretary general.

item.title: Fading Economy and Graft Crackdown Rattle Chinaâ€™s Leaders
item.description: A slowdown could mark the end of fast growth, while a campaign against official corruption has continued longer and reached higher than most had expected.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and JONATHAN ANSFIELD
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China with President Obama in Beijing last year. Mr. Jinping will be visiting Washington in a few weeks.

item.title: 2 American Service Members Foil Gunman in Train Attack
item.description: The two men averted carnage by tackling an armed, suspected terrorist on a high-speed train traveling from Amsterdam to France, officials said.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Several passengers were wounded Friday when a man opened fire aboard a train from Amsterdam to Paris. One arrest was made.
